answers.answer: Hello and I am very sorry to hear of your condition. Our stories are very similar. I spent 2 wks in hosp and was released on 1-08-08 with diagnosis very very similar to yours. I am 49 yr Male, 6'3, 189lbs, clean coronary arteries, healthy B/P.  I can totally relate as to how confused and overwhelmed you must feel. I am also told that I need an ICD, and I am reluctant to have one implanted.Do you have any arrhythmia issues in addition to your Cardiomyopathy?  I suffer from many pvcs and have had runs of V-tach.  My cardio has me on Coreg also, as well as accupril, simvastitin, and spironolactone.Do you also have an enlarged LV? CHF?  I am trying to figure all this out also. Hang in there ! I realize my post isn't very informative (sorry), but sometimes there is comfort in support. I hope this helps you somewhat. Be well

I am sorry for your troubles as well!  I have no Arrhythmias.  I have irregular hearats sounds and a murmur that at the lower left sternal border that radiates to the left ventriculat apex.  I am on Coreg, Lisinoprol, and Hydrochloroxide.  What were you sypmtoms that took you to the hospital in the first place?  I just kept feeling like a need to yawn to get a deep breath.  If I stopped dead in my tracks and yawned it would usually help for a few minutes.  Pepole always thought I was so tired and nned sleep.

Hello again.  Believe it or not, I went to ER with severe abdominal pain. Need gall bladder to be removed. After sonogram for abdomen, Dr's noticed abnormalities... yada-yada. Wouldn't give me cardiac clearance for surgery... Next thing I know, the boom lowered with this condition.Looking back, I was having bouts of SOB, fatigue, etc. ( initially blamed it on injuries from an accident yrs ago).I am not a Dr (obviously) but your need to yawn, is probably from your need for oxygen. Since your heart is pumping inefficiently, your body is receiving diminished supply of oxygenated blood from heart. ( when we yawn, it usually is from the need for more oxygen). Your cardiologist can request a Cardiopulmonary exercise test to help give you info as to how your lungs/ heart are interacting .As for ICD (defib), your EF, as well as mine, puts us in the 'severe' heart failure range ( if 15-20 % is accurate). So with today's clinical protocol; cardiomyopathy with ef less than 30% ( 29 and under is HF), warrants implantation of ICD.I am still trying to accept this as I prepare for this procedure. ( Trying to decide whether or not to get extended warranty with it, ;-)  ).  Be well.

question: I am a 50 year old women with no previous health issues or family history of heart issues other than for the last 6 months I sporatically would experience shortness of breath.  I have been dianosed through the normal testing on Jan 10, 2008  with Non Ischemic Cardiomyopathy, LV ejection fraction of 15-20%, severe hypokinesis to akinesis of the anteroseptal segments with overall severe left ventrile systolic dysfunction.  No underlying coronary artery disease.  Treatment is Coreg (right now at 12.5 mgs per day) to be doubled soon and Lisinopril 5 mg daily. After 3 months I am to have an echo to evaluate any progress.  If there is no progress how long should I wait before having a defibrillator or defibrillator/biventricular pacemaker inserted?  Ny dr says it can take up to 9 months.  I am of normal weight, blood pressure, cholesteral, no diabetes, non smoke and non drinker.  Thanks so much!
title: Severe Left Ventricle Systolic Dysfunction
